title: Great place to work
pros: Friendly co-workers, great benefits, lgbtq friendly, too many to name!
cons: None that I can think of.

title: Big company pay, small company feel
pros: Fair comp plan Leaders that care Great colleagues
cons: Strict scheduling No longer allowing remote work

title: Toxic Culture That Destroys Morale and Wellbeing
pros: One manager at the site level genuinely cared and tried to support their team. Talented coworkers who do their best despite the environment. Strong name recognition.
cons: This is not just a “high-pressure sales job.” It’s a culture built on fear, intimidation, and exhaustion. The division prioritizes metrics over people, and it shows in every aspect of the employee experience. Fear Over Feedback: Speaking up is dangerous. Employees who voice concerns are quickly labeled as negative or a “problem.” HR is not a safe option, and feedback sessions are tightly controlled to avoid real criticism. Unrealistic Metrics: Success is measured by spreadsheets, not actual effort or customer experience. Performance standards are punishing and often based on factors outside employees’ control. Call Distribution Games: Leads are not distributed evenly. Some get better calls while others are left with recycled, low-quality prospects—yet everyone is held to the same national targets. The system is fundamentally unfair. Health Toll: The stress here is extreme. Employees report anxiety, burnout, sleeplessness, and the feeling that work consumes their lives. The lack of acknowledgment from leadership only deepens the damage. Revolving Door: Turnover is constant. People leave burned out and disillusioned. Many return briefly out of necessity, only to leave again once they find something healthier.

title: A Soul-Crushing Machine Disguised as a Job
pros: • You might make money if you get golden leads (don’t count on it). • Base pay during non-tenured months gives you temporary breathing room.
cons: Training is a joke: six weeks of slide decks and half-baked “shadowing” where you often can’t even hear the borrower. You’re thrown in blind and blamed when you sink. • Non-tenure lasts ~3 months. Sounds safe—until your last non-tenured month rolls over and drags down your first three months of tenure. You’re haunted by numbers you had no chance to escape. • Calls are a trap: you can lock as many as you want, but if they don’t fund, you’re accused of “costing the company” thousands. Instead of coaching, you get public shaming. • Leadership is chaos. Some managers hide, others panic, all live in fear. Genuine support is extinct. The culture is built on intimidation, finger-pointing, and fear. • Toxicity is woven into every metric. You can fund loans and still be told you’re failing. The system is designed to chew you up and spit you out. • Upcoming comp plan change—expect to work harder each year for less.

title: Wizard of OZ
pros: Stress, wrinkles and annoying managers
cons: Working at PennyMac was a highly discouraging experience. The culture is heavily micromanaged, leaving little room for trust or autonomy. Compensation is below industry standards, and the workload is consistently overwhelming due to chronic understaffing. Employees are expected to take on far more than is reasonable, which quickly leads to burnout and frustration. Opportunities for career growth are minimal, and employee well-being doesn’t seem to be a priority. Overall, PennyMac places too much emphasis on control and output, while failing to invest in its people. I would not recommend this company to anyone seeking fair pay, balance, or a supportive environment.

title: safe but boring

title: Untrustworthy Organization
pros: Excellent pay, they are at the center of the correspondent secondary markets and are well positioned and well capitalized. You can learn a ton and get great experience.
cons: Hyper political environment, some of the worst aspects of the old Countrywide culture. If you aren't personally aligned with the right senior execs, you can get laid off in an instant. Very little loyalty, litany of carnage of VPs to EVPs who were screwed over but then given a pay off to sign non-disparagement agreements. If you get an offer from them, ask for a guaranteed severance package. If they won't provide it, don't accept the offer.

title: Executives with Zero Industry Experience and will Over Hire and Fire without no Recourse

cons: Executives and Managers have zero clue about the mortgage industry and make decisions proving that. If you’re an experienced LO or mortgage industry candidate this place will blow your mind due to its size and cluelessness‼️

title: Great managers and interesting work
pros: I really like my job at PennyMac. The work is challenging and the development culture is really great. I feel fully supported by my leaders and enjoy the people. Culture is good.
cons: This company is obsessed with RTO. You have to fill out an online form to be able to WFH and they set the goal of in office of 85% of the time, meaning you can only WFH once every 2 weeks.

title: It's a job that doesn't value you.
pros: Health insurance premiums, while high, did not raise in cost year to year. They gave an additional 5 days of PTO this year. The office environment is pretty casual and friendly. Management tries to keep it fun with provided lunches & optional after work events. If you do your job, no one bothers you about being on your phone during calls.
cons: There are no annual raises. It doesn't matter how well you perform yearly, your pay will never increase which means you are losing money the longer you work. They do not promote from within, I have been fully qualified yet rejected while the jobs are offered to external candidates. Pennymac decided to spend hundreds of millions of dollars sponsoring the Olympics one day after the CEO sold nearly 7,000 stock shares and a lot of their execs seem to have sold a lot of their stock in the months post election. The sick time is given as a bundle of 40 hours that replenishes annually on your anniversary, and you earn a little over 3 hours PTO every two weeks. The management is very anti-WFH and will rarely give you that option even on a holiday.

title: Great place to have a career
pros: Opportunities for Advancement, Steady pay increases for hard work, great people, relaxed work environment, work life balance. Benefits are good, good match on 401k, Nice office.
cons: I think the company values speed and agility to the detriment of accuracy, execution, and efficiency. The company could really benefit from a robust, and ongoing, operations training program, especially in the Retail and TPO channels. The company needs a consistent hybrid WFH policy, needs to abandon a full RTO policy, and needs to re-implement hybrid for higher management levels. These positions are hard to hire for, and we've already lost several highly valued and high performing individuals at higher management levels due to a no remote/ hybrid policy at those levels.

Mgmt Hired based on connections- not industry experience. Critical thinking is not appreciated- just the ability to follow instructions. Integrity may not be a valued trait.

Lots of metrics to hit with some not relative to loans fundings. High levels of micromanagement. Whole department set to monitor loan officers every move (Retail Control Tower). No upwards mobility

title: Never work at a company you wouldn't do business with
pros: Lunch purchased for office at least once a week. Nice office space. Good location where office is located.
cons: Other Loan Officers steal loans from one another. Four months after starting they lowered everyone's pay company wide. Terrible processing department, People with VP titles who do not have work experience or life experience and it shows. Training is terrible. My class had a guy who has never trained a day in his life and only in the mortgage business for a year. Had 60 loans in pipeline and only ten closed, caught underwriting and processing turning down loans incorrectly, Purposely delaying loan closings by a few days to prevent people from making high bonus, several questionable practices and in the State of TN commission is supposed to be paid within 30 days, you're lucky if you see that money in three months. Way too many emails, financial software that is so outdated and not conducive to doing the job.

title: Love Pennymac!
pros: There's lots of room for growth and career development. Love my team and the people I work with!
cons: No cons at this time.

title: There are a lot of pros and cons
pros: Less red tape than most companies in regards to cross team problem solving and collaboration. Friendly and supportive management that let you play into your strengths and develop new skills.
cons: Very pushy on the in office collaboration and resistance of remote and hybrid options. Culture is very college fraternity/sorority feeling. Very slow at pay raises. There are no yearly cost of living or merit raises only "market adjustments" every 2-3 years. Bonuses are capped at a certain percentage. So even if you do go "above and beyond" you get the same bonus as your slacker teammate. The mortgage industry is very feast or famine. I survived 2 layoffs at the beginning and then working a skeleton crews until rates got better. In busy season management tends to give all resources and energy to new hires and leaves more senior people to figure things out on there own.

title: Upper Management is too much
pros: The people here are great and mostly all of us get along.
cons: Upper management has turned into control freaks. Employees are judged and viewed based on numbers on a screen but not the quality of their work. Most departments have to report to the office every day. Some still have hybrid, but if you utilize their hybrid schedule you will get scolded and will have it used against you if you want a promotion or raise (not that they’d give you one anyways). The company has a whole has a “control” problem where they have this old school mentality of wanting to control people. They will find every excuse in the book to delay and put off raises/promotions, but will swing and change an entire organization over night. They will constantly tell you why they “can’t” do things that would benefit the employee, but will change the entire dynamic of the department on a moments notice when it does t benefit the employees.

The use their Penny Pantry as a way of an incentive for having to be fully on site. The CEO hates Work from home models and currently in the process of eliminating this. The CEO and executives prefer to eliminate departments instead of giving justified pay raises for the work load presented. Growth is not a priority with PENNYMAC.

title: Great Enviornment to Build Career and Network

title: Terrible

title: Legal Theft
pros: Income was decent during low rate environment. End of Pros.
cons: Company looks for every avenue in which to exploit a LOs job security as well as commission payouts. Micromanaged every minute of every hour of every day, with the threat of being terminated held over your head daily. Absurd metrics that must be met on a daily basis. Calls are recorded and monitored by a 3rd party company, by people who's only job is to make sure you read every single word on every single page of the company's 10 page sales script. You miss one word and you are hit with a critical fail, which not only places you in the termination pile-but the company then keeps your commission on that loan when it funds. Technology that is spotty at best, taking up to 30 minutes simply to get logged into the system. If you're more than 5 minutes late logging in to your shift, you are written up -all because Pennymacs servers are bogged down and won't let you in. Multiple months in which I would miss hitting 125% payouts on commission by 1 funding unit-only to see that unit literally fund the very next day on the 1st of the next month. This alone costs me tens of thousands of dollars every quarter in commissions. Shady practices and nonpayment of entitled commissions to loan officers should be scrutinized and red flagged by government entities, because clearly this is not legal and unethical. Hmmm....this just gave me an idea.

title: Lies and deception

Some of the most poisonous culture I’ve ever worked with in my entire life. I’m so happy I left. Honestly, don’t trust anything they say. The grass is definitely greener on the other side, so run.

title: Unfair treatment
pros: Not many pros I can think of.
cons: I work on an underwriting team of 15. I took a promotion and only got a pay increase of $1000 from my non underwriting role. Also the 13 other underwriters get to be fully remote and due to a hot head VP, two of us have to work In the office. We have brought up to him multiple times how it isn’t fair to make the 2 of us office employees when the other 13 are fully remote and his response is he doesn’t care, it is what it is so get over it. Our direct supervisor is remote and we don’t even have anyone to report to so we are essentially alone at the office.

title: Horrible Company/Management
pros: Please run, don't walk. Stay away from this place.
cons: This is easily one of the worst companies I have ever had the displeasure of working for. 0 Raises. They'll make up some BS like "Oh our budget only allows for this and this, but not this. If you want a raise, you'll have to go above and beyond and do things outside of your pay grade to receive it". I had this job because I need money, not because I need to break my back (metaphorically) being overworked. Management has absolutely 0 concept of actual managing. They not only lack people skills, but they lack the ability to do what their title entails, manage. I understand micromanaging comes with the territory, but that's not the issue. Nobody is ever on the same page. Constant disagreements on how to do something. Only for them to come back and change their answer again, and again, and again. Additionally, they have a toxic mindset and constantly threaten our job. They tell us to "change our mindset" when we are telling them we're overworked. Heaven forbid you have a complaint. "Deal with it" is the typical response. They have the whole, "it's my way or the highway' approach. Look at the decline in reviews. There's a reason. Please stay far, far away.

pros: Great if you're just starting in your career, fresh out of college and want to get some experience from an established company in the mortgage industry. It is respectable work and you can pivot into different areas of tech and product through the mortgage application process.
cons: Not much room to grow and the pay is not the best in comparison to the market rate. Even after a promotion they lag behind competitors. Management is also very old school. In a society where most things can be done electronically, the company is lead by old school copywriters and file cabinets where they refuse to adapt to the resources most tech companies use today. Turnover has also been high this past year, as it seems with every interest rate hike was followed by a round of layoffs. Most of the problems that the teams face have already been discovered but management refuses to invest into addressing them.

title: Great Experience with Consummate Professionals
pros: Working at PennyMac has been one of the most rewarding professional experiences I’ve ever had. The environment is marked by a high level of professionalism and courtesy. The team, from upper management to entry-level employees, is composed of genuine and kind individuals. The company is situated in a prime area with a reasonable commute, enhancing the overall work-life balance. During the COVID lockdowns, PennyMac demonstrated its commitment to employee well-being by providing care packages and thoughtful gifts, which were a nice touch. Management is highly accessible and possesses a diverse range of expertise, always ready to offer guidance. I appreciate the company’s metrics-driven approach, which fosters transparency and clear expectations. I am enthusiastic about the prospect of returning to PennyMac after completing my degree and look forward to advancing my career here with higher compensation.
cons: ummate Professionals

title: Training is horrible, access to data takes forever
pros: I liked the culture, most people were friendly
cons: I worked there for only a month, and wasn't able to even start doing my job for 2 weeks due to bad training and no access to the data that I required. The team I worked with was on a hybrid schedule, so they worked M-F in office, then Th- Fri were from home. I was only trained a couple of hours a day for the first 3 days I was there, then left to figure it out. This means figuring out a new system, new processes, etc. The Processes and Procedures was horribly written and left out a lot of important material, especially if you got an Error message which happened a lot with the horrible system they use, so on Thursdays and Fridays I tried using them when I was finally given work to do, but made mistakes due to the P/P's missing a whole lot of information. Then if I wanted to ask a question I got dirty looks and slow answers to my questions. When I was let go I still didn't have access to all of the databases that I needed, (it took them 2 weeks just to get me a phone) so I don't feel like they even gave me a chance to prove myself, and the team lead seemed like she didn't want to help or answer any questions. But then when I made a mistake she was all over me for it, and not in a positive way. I appreciate feedback when it is constructive, but they way she did it was demeaning and demoralizing. I was moving work along by the 3rd week and completing the tasks they gave me, and doing my best to figure it out on my own, but that wasn't enough I guess. Some of they other teams seemed to work together, this team didn't want to help or work as a team. If I asked the manager for help, which wasn't often because she was so busy, I would get a patronizing look and answer, like " you should know this". Well, if I would have had real training and P&P's that were written well, I wouldn't have to be asking you questions. would I?

title: Profit over people
pros: Paycheck Job security Co-workers Paid Time Off (when you're not forced to use it for regional emergencies)
cons: With a hurricane approaching, I was shocked that my employer expected, if not demanded, that I come into the office or use Paid Time Off. The local government issued mandatory emergency evacuations and told people to stay home. The US government suspended mail service. Bridges in the Tampa Bay area were closed to traffic, as well as city streets. Yet Pennymac told us to ignore these orders and come into the office. We are constantly told how important employees are, but we only seem to matter when we're closing loans, not when you and your family's safety is on the line. People forced to come into the officer found elevators out of service for "safety" reasons. We've been told repeatedly to go online and vote for Pennymac as a "best place to work" but a best place to work doesn't prioritize loan processing over human lives during a hurricane.

title: A Company Trying to be New School with Old School Toxicity
pros: There's hybrid flexibility for most roles. I would say the pay is decent. Work-life balance is ok to a point. There is some attempt at employee engagement but I did not see a lot in my time there.
cons: There was a major focus on production for my role, which was not clearly defined as a production role when I agreed to the position. Loans reviewed per hour are heavily scrutinized by management in order to maximize employee productivity. Failing to hit a certain number per hour meant that an employee would be reprimanded for productivity. The department's ultimate goal is to have a team of 2 to 3 employees do as much as possible within a workday, rather than employing the appropriate number of employees to handle the workload. The end result is employees become micromanaged to ensure that a rigid production schedule is met that isn't necessary and can be obtained by other means. When the workload is very heavy, other departments are often recruited to help disposition files. As one may have guessed, the end result is that many arbitrary errors are found when the files are reviewed. There is no consistency about what the job is meant to be or how day-to-day processes should be conducted between frontline employees, middle management, and top management. Front-line specialists may have. completely different understanding of how certain scenarios should be handled than management. Because of this, new employees may become frustrated or confused because of the different answers that may receive when asking questions. Management lacks actual managerial skills and many are in leadership roles due to being high producers in their past positions. This is a common trope within the mortgage industry, and it would even seem like an appropriate idea if managers were expected to produce just as their subordinates are. However, this is not the case. Managers in this department are strictly salaried supervisors and their expectations are to lead, coach, and give feedback. Since they were promoted for past production and not their potential to motivate and influence employees, they lack the necessary skills to accomplish their intended goal. The end result is that there is a hyper-fixation on production with little to no feedback detailing how to improve or a realistic view that some days production can vary. Essentially middle management views their position as literal micromanagement, leading to a toxic work culture. From personal experience, not only was my hourly production monitored closely, but my emails were monitored by management to ensure screenshots looked appropriate. There are also times when I was reprimanded for not answering an email quickly enough, even when the email had been received within 30 minutes and not marked as urgent. Not only is severe micromanagement an issue, but some managers have no way to conduct themselves in the office. My manager made a habit of frequent inappropriate remarks/stories. These ranged from stories of drug use to a remark made regarding a physical I had requested PTO for.

title: Remove Unnecessary Parts and Pay Better
pros: Great mid-level management that truly cares about you. They are pretty flexible with you within reason when you have urgent matters come up when life happens. They cater in lunch from time to time and do employee appreciation events. Cafeteria with awesome food options at an affordable cost to employees.
cons: Very segmented workflows and processes comparatively to other companies which results in terrible pay. This also slows down your production drastically which makes it difficult to hit quotas that are necessary to bonus. The pay is way below industry standards and upper management is the problem, like above the VP, etc. They hire people with decades of experience at very entry level cost. New loan operating system for some of the departments has a lot of kinks, but they are actively working on this. Training and development of new hires needs some work, but they are also actively working on it. The bonus structure is abysmal too, way over complicated and is paid quarterly. They cannot keep educated overqualified candidates because they are underpaying so much, so it’s a revolving door when those employees find better paying jobs.

title: I Was Warned…
pros: - I had THEE absolute BEST manager on the PLANET (RW) and I honestly couldn’t have handpicked a better group of coworkers. - Decent benefits - Decent pay - Received a promotion while working from home
cons: *sigh* - As trainers, we were on a rolling 6 week class schedule with literally ZERO time off. When I first began, I went five months without so much as a half day to go to a doctor’s appointment. Every trainer was on this schedule, so there was no opportunity for backup or standby in case the primary trainer had any kind of emergency. I worked sick, with a broke down car in my garage that I couldn’t take to the shop…yeah. - No continuity with the line of business. Our procedures and manuals were embarrassingly outdated and I always felt horrible knowing that the information we were giving participants would be COMPLETELY different once they actually started doing the work. - We were forced to turn in report cards weekly to track individual improvement…not the easiest feat when there are 20 people in your class - and again, you don’t have any type of help. - I went on leave and had to email HR and ask them when I was returning. They took three days to answer me. I returned on the day they gave me, reached out to them and again…three days of nothing. Once they finally acknowledged me, I received a check with two instead of five days of pay because THEY chose to disregard the fact that I was there. - Everything had changed when I returned. We’d returned to the office and gone to a “modular” training style, where we could share one another’s load and not train every single day. Seemed cool, but I wondered why we had to come into the office if we 1) were still training virtually, and 2) not working on a particular day. No joke…out of a 6 week class, I was only scheduled to train 4 days - but was still expected to come in the office every day (in terrible traffic)? Made NO sense. I would go to work, literally sit and do nothing, and go home. I’d ask for extra work/projects to no avail. - What kind of company pushes their employees to go back into the office when gas prices were literally the highest in HISTORY?! A California based company at that, where gas prices are the highest! Completely insensitive and callous call. Also, I was told that going back into the office helped with revenue for the county/city…but I live in the same county/city as the building, so they could have kept that lie for somebody else. - Of the three departments in our division, one was totally remote and the other was Hybrid. It was hard not to take having to come in daily (again, most days for nothing) personally. We kept hearing “PennyMac is a WFO company”, but kept pulling up to a half empty building every day. Whatever the COMPANY is doing, that’s what the COMPANY as a WHOLE needs to do. - Three hours of vacation a paycheck is an absolute joke. You have to work a year just to get a week’s vacation. It’s insane!!!! And I’ve heard “HR is working on it” since I got there in 2019.

title: Must Avoid
pros: You can make a lot of money quickly. Many of my coworkers were nice people
cons: I was originally part of the college development program. If you’re a student this company is a must avoid. They constantly lie to tell you how great of a company they are and how going to any other company to do the job would be a mistake. This was my first red flag here. In my 6 months as a loan officer for Pennymac I had 3 different managers. My first one I was in office still in training and they put me on the only remote team there. Following that they demoted my manager and put me on an in office team, only to demote my manager again. Finally I was put on a more secure team although management at that point was all micromanagement. The work life balance is terrible. Overtime is not optional or is required by the company although they disguise it as optional. The recruiter who hired me told me multiple different lies that I then realized we’re not true when I came to the job. There is tons of micromanagement at the company and upper management always plays favorites. Unless you are a favorite, don’t expect to be treated well by anyone there. The office culture is horrible. The people working there never faced consequences for making jokes about other employees that were often times hurtful and terrible to even witness. I’ve witnessed people out loud make school shooter jokes and racist jokes about other employees and everything is shrugged off. I almost felt uncomfortable speaking to others in the office as I did not want to be at the end of a joke they found humorous that I found offensive. Our site (tampa) constantly finished the lowest of any site for production and this isn’t because of the loan officers there. This is because of the poor management spearheaded by the site lead who proceeded to mismanage the site from the moment I was there. If you’re looking for a place of employment you feel comfortable in, I would avoid Pennymac at all costs unless you find racism and hatred a part of your daily life. I’m glad I no longer work for Pennymac as it was the worst choice I could have ever made graduating university.

cons: Office politics, top producers get special treatment. Corporate BS.

title: Finance
pros: Absolutely no micromanaging if you are basically competent and quick thinking. You will be given very easy to follow task and not required to critically think past solving a problem by just calling someone or walking over to someone. If you get lucky to get a manager in a different state, then you really will hardly physically, have to talk to anyone. Very quiet environment, almost like a freaking library. I say this with the utmost seriousness and as judgement free as possible. Only women get promoted here, it’s just the facts. If you are an educated, witty, proficient problem solver with incredible people skills, you will be surprised how the promotion opportunities will dangle in front you period full stop. There
cons: They pay is atrocious, not a living wage ($20/hr) there were no “merit increases” Y.O.Y and only quarterly bonus that are tiny. They told people there will be a mandatory return to site and it looked like maybe 30% - 40% actually listened. They will tell you they want people to work in the office for the culture. There is no culture, most people working there are either afraid to lose their job or to scared to quit. People litterally sit at their desks right now and do nothing because mortgage environment is so slow because interest rates. Only the people in your immediate group / team are the people you will naturally have communication with unless you are incredibly extroverted and force your way into other groups / people. There are NO team building / company happy hours.

title: A bit dysfunctional

title: Great work environment!

cons: I loved this company, nothing bad to say.

title: Slow to adjust to changing times
pros: Decent Pay Non-contentious inter-departmental communication within divisions Direct management willing to work with you to try and balance work/life
cons: Unwillingness to adjust work-location to accommodate health conditions Driving away long-time employees in a demand to have everyone return to office. Upper management is tone-deaf to changes in the job market and employee expectations, ignoring easy cost neutral ways to improve employee quality of life and save money on real estate. Time-Off is not usable until accrued forcing newer employees to work when sick or take unpaid time off to accommodate family emergencies. Pay increases are almost non-existent. Annual bonuses are paid out in 2 halves, 6 months apart and if you leave before receiving the 2nd half you forfeit it. This is a bonus from the previous year and should not be held hostage in this way. Frequent meetings that are pointless due to hosts who do not prepare participants for what to expect.

title: It's a job
pros: My co-workers/managers are some of the most down to earth and friendly people I've had the pleasure of working with. Dress code is pretty relaxed which is a nice benefit too
cons: Upper management is completely out of touch. They wont change goals in a changing market which means you will get paid a lot less when things get tough. Specifically if you don't fund more than 4 loans they will take 50% of your pay check as punishment. One month the average for 120 employees was 5 fundings which means they only give you 90% of your earnings. Additionally, if you're a new hire and you don't meet their unrealistic goals the "bonus" they give you will have to be paid back too. It would be a lot easier to stomach if everyone else in the process wasn't salaried so they don't care if your loans fund. Other than that, you're not allowed to work from home but they encourage working OT at home. Being a call center, you can't make phone calls using personal Bluetooth headsets as it's a "security issue" but I can connect to 10 different TVs on my phone. Only 2 weeks of PTO which is discouraged, and all benefits have been taken away. We used to get food on fridays and have GrubHub plus but now we get nothing and we've recently been told no more coffee cups will be provided and we need to bring our own.

title: Run Don’t Walk
pros: Some of my co-workers and teammates

Selling to their employees that “we hire contractors in India so we don’t do layoffs here”. We all know that’s not true, due to Zoom meetings with mass layoffs…$10 they still have contractors in India.

title: Think twice about a corporate job
pros: Good salary and bonus plan Generally upbeat and positive environment Good cafeteria Very big DEI focus, though it can be to the point where people are afraid to open their mouths for fear of saying something wrong
cons: Expensive insurance. It's cut in half if you participate in the wellness program, but even half is expensive. Stingy vacation, with no improvement for five years and even then only if you're a VP or higher. Mandatory in office for vice president and above. You might be eligible for hybrid under that, but your boss will be in the office and this is definitely an office-first culture. Miserable open office, for everyone under SVP level. Research says you'll be unhappy and unproductive, so be aware of what you're walking into. CEO cult. In the midst of massive layoffs and loads of empty office space, they actually opened another office so the CEO wouldn't have to commute but could still say he was on site. Nobody seems willing to speak against what he wants. For some positions - not sure which ones - no annual salary review, so be sure to ask if that's true for your situation

title: The Worst Place to Work

title: Worst place to work
pros: The only pros for this job is when they offered unlimited overtime, other than that nothing.
cons: Careless upper management, no work life balance, too many unkept promises. No advancement, no matter how hard you work, 2 faced gossiping people, similar like high-school drama

title: Countrywide 2.0?
pros: My direct manager was fantastic, and the onsite facilities were pretty good. Which is handy, considering they practically wanted you to live there.
cons: I predict that PennyMac will have severe issues within the next 2 years similar to Countrywide. Upper management has an extremely adversarial stance against all internal governance efforts; to the point that they browbeat you into removing findings from reports. They are compensated for not having findings, so rather than work on fixing anything, they just fight and whine until they are removed off reports. Everyone loses when that happens. On a personal note they expected 60 hrs a week to be normal starting point, so a normal work-life balance was impossible; and I had recently been laid off my prior job so they brought me in at 2 levels lower and a severely cut paycheck because they knew they could take advantage of my situation. It wasn't until I resigned, and they realized just how much I brought to the table, that they attempted to bring me back to a level near what I had previous. Is it any surprise that talent doesn't stick around? Oh and good luck getting the 3-4 weeks of vacation everyone else is providing, they only offer 2 here.

Benefits are super expensive and 401k only after a year of being on the job. 2 weeks vacation that has to be accrued.

title: Pretty good or kinda lame depending on department
pros: If you are not working on the production side of things, you will enjoy good work life balance. I actually really enjoyed the first three years at PennyMac in the office before they closed down two other offices and crammed everyone in. WLB was great, and I didn't mind the lower salary because of that. Once I switched to production, WLB was not always great, and we were often asked to work weekends and work past 5. Mind-numbing multi-hour meetings were also the norm. Final Assessment: If you're early on in your programming career, this is a good place to build some experience and then bounce. If you're later in your career, it's a good place to coast until you retire.
cons: - Will not allow fully remote workers - Less than market rate salary. As a senior, you can expect to make 40k less than the current average - Kind of a boring industry to be in, and it's often difficult to bridge the gap of understanding between the "business people" and the programmers unless you already have knowledge of this industry - Working on production = working on the weekends, a million slack channels with people fighting fires, 1+ hour long zoom calls. - Periodic layoffs - Every month you have to do these boring compliance training courses that take at least an hour and have jack squat to do with your job

title: Great Place to work
pros: We are one big Family here at PennyMac. I have been here just over 4 years and have had 3 promotions . PennyMac has great career opportunities and amazing benefits for anyone looking to grow with an established company. If you are in a a career path with another company and feel like your stuck with no growth opportunity’s I would suggest attend one of many job fairs or you log in to our web site hit the career tab and load a copy of your resume . I am always excited to see new faces that have what it takes to be a part of the fastest growing Mortgage servicer out there right now. If you are excited by reading this what are you waiting for ? Reach out and see what it feels like to be appreciated and work for an amazing company with lots of growth opportunities. See you Soon…
cons: I honestly can’t think of any Cons working here ....I Love my Job. Senior management believes in a work, family balance and are here to support you anytime you need them. Do you get this in your current employer? Don't you feel you should? Well what are you waiting for?

title: Worst career decision I've ever made
pros: It's fairly easy to get a job at PennyMac. If you are at the end the rope and having trouble making ends meet, then *and only then* consider a job at PennyMac. This is a destination of last resort.
cons: I don't know where to begin. I'll start by saying there is absolutely no job security. People get fired or laid-off all the time on the whim of management. Stan and the other executives will fire anyone and everyone who is not in the C-suite if it will save them a dollar. The company swings from one focus to another depending on what can earn the executives the most money. One day they're focused on servicing, the next on technology, then commercial. Whole groups are turned over or transferred without warning. PennyMac has horrible benefits. They don't care about there employees so why provide benefits? Again, the only thing that matters is how much money can the executives make. Employees are costs to them. The place is basically an arena for unemployable Countrywide Home Loans / BofA alumni to reunite. Bonuses are promised and never paid. The 401K plan doesn't let you in until 1 year of service. Vacation, sick, and holiday time are the worst in class. All the employees joke about how awful it is on a daily basis. Laughing about it is the only way to get by.

title: Careless, Classless, Greedy Company
pros: Potential Work From Home, 50k starting salary in most positions
cons: No valuable work experience, you’re just a number to them, they do not care about you or view you as a human, they’re never satisfied with your work, unappreciative, constantly pressure you into transitioning into a role that will make them more money even if it’s not in your best interest, will lay you off without severance, “mandatory overtime?” will make you keep working outside of your agreed upon hours even though your contract says that you’re not obligated to, will change your schedule without you having a say. Overall, not much positivity to take from company, and I feel a huge sense of relief no longer being affiliated with a company like this.

title: Good
pros: 2 days work from home
cons: higher management changes a lot

title: Analyst
pros: Good experience with SQL databases
cons: Not a competitive pay scale

title: Wouldn't do it again.
pros: Nice facilities, and clean location
cons: Bad work culture, wasn't a great place to work

title: Low Pay
pros: I enjoy the company and team I work with
cons: Don't make much money if moving up through the company

title: Cog in a Machine
pros: Work is consistent. You usually aren’t expected to step out of your assigned scope.
cons: Little to no opportunity for cross-training. You definitely feel like you are a nameless cog to leadership. You are also very very expendable.

title: No work life balance
pros: At the time, they allowed remote work
cons: there was no work-life balance

title: It’s okay
pros: - management is okay -Hr is not helpful
cons: -No work life balance -

title: Displeased
pros: * culture and diversity * benefits * cafeterias
cons: * lack of proper training * terrible employee turnover rate * leadership and upper management unorganized, with some displaying their elitism towards others in unprofessional manner

title: Analyst
pros: The culture and the coworkers
cons: Work environment and workload. Career progression is slow and pay is below average.

title: Loan Officer at PennyMac
pros: Heavy amount of warm inbound leads every day that come straight from a very large portfolio of current customers. There are so many leads it's almost a problem trying to deal with them all. I have not made one cold call in my career here. Compensation is strong with most loan officers making well over 6 figures. Top guys can make $200k+/yr. They promote almost exclusively from within the company if you are looking for career advancement.
cons: Call center environment with heavy focus on metrics. Systems are sluggish and the technology needs some love. Work/life balance can be tough sometimes with long hours.

title: Average
pros: You learn alot in excel and it's a goof first corporate job
cons: Slow growth and the pay is avg

title: Great before the layoffs
pros: Good management, benefits were fair, decent bonus structure
cons: No raises in underwriting department. Pay could’ve been better

title: Don’t do it
pros: Good money at times when times are good
cons: Micromanagement old school tactics horrible treatment of employees with constant threats of loosing your job

title: Good company to learn mortgage
pros: Lots of experienced people in the industry work at Pennymac
cons: The job itself is busy and bland. Management can also play favorites

title: It was good
pros: I work with PennyMac 6 year and was laid off.
cons: Recognize and acknowledge the good employees .

title: Title
pros: The people, coworkers made it bearable
cons: Low pay, no yearly raises

title: Not everyone career place
pros: Good to learn in an early career
cons: Friends and family company in there

title: Management not the best
pros: Great commission pay when rates are good
cons: Base pay is not the best

title: Good place to start career, but with some issues
pros: Good starting pay, lots of learning opportunities
cons: Raises/promotions are virtually non existent Leadership is weak

title: Miserable company to work for if you work in the Loan Servicing department!
pros: Since it is a new company, employees do not have to spend an inordinate amount of time on conference calls or in unproductive meetings. Not a lot of Bureaucracy to deal with as compared to a large company. The company offers free parking and has a pretty decent on site cafeteria.
cons: Avoid the Loan Servicing department at all costs as it has a very high school environment, and certain managers are absolutely horrendous to work for. There is a certain manager in the Loan Servicing department who I would say has the personality of a rattlesnake, but that would be an insult to the overall rattlesnake community. Speaking of which, she and her boss, and her bosses’ boss are all snakes! They are all very unprofessional, and often criticize other peers and Managers in front of their employees. They make promises and commitments that they have no intention of honoring, and are generally very unethical, dishonest people whom no one should ever trust. In addition, employees are overloaded with work and expected to work long hours, for which they are only rewarded with more work. An employee can do a great job on a thousand things, and it will go unrecognized, if not unnoticed, but make just one mistake and you’ll never hear the end of it. In summary, it’s a sweatshop!

title: Positive experience
pros: Team oriented, friendly co workers,
cons: None that I can think of

title: Countrywide all over in it's worst way!
pros: It's a paycheck another job to add to your resume.
cons: The dynamics of micro managing is real. All managers are not trained properly. Colleagues depend on other colleagues for answers. Your not a processor or point of contact at all. Your a call center representative with a pipeline. Other teams are not held to any accountability at all so you have to deal with yelling customers. Favoritism is so real. Spreadsheets, emails, inbound calls fixing the files of teammates, and still trying to stay on top of your customers It's a circus. Escalating is a joke unless you have a good manager as nothing will get done. Training for new employees is not sufficient at all. Even if you have the experience there process is not easy to follow. No balance to work life. If there's an issue your best bet is to try to figure out out yourself if you have an angry customer not yours on the line good luck getting help. Your not a processor no where near it. This can effect your efforts in getting a job with a traditional company that actually conducts processing only! You are required to wait quarterly for your bonus. The excuse provided was so they can get your final numbers faster verses monthly bonuses! Don't be fooled you'll see your money in the bank faster then the final amount given. Company this big does not offer Kaiser for medical.

title: Flexible Work, Poor Management
pros: Flexible work hours and vacation time
cons: Poor management and advancement opportunities

title: 1 to 2 year Career Outlook
pros: Learn Basics - Loan Processing and Underwriting Solid Training Option to work Remote
cons: Micromanagement Style Repetitive Limited Job Opportunities during Interest Rate Change

title: I wish I made enough money to buy a noose
pros: Certain people are smart and fun to work with. They are intelligent, forward thinking, and hard working. These people give me hope and think that I don't need to buy a noose anymore.
cons: 90% of this company are uneducated clock watching, paycheck collecting lazy employees that do the minimum required to get by. Pay no attention to detail and refuses to pick up the phone.

title: Great job with great income potentials but processing issues are frustrating
pros: - high compensation - satisfying work - the company is growing quickly and investing into things like technology - my manager supports me and helps me when I need it. - the job is pretty simple once you get it down. It’s a sales job so the main difficulty is keeping your energy up. Once you’ve done it for a few months, you will have a pretty good grasp of the work itself
cons: - appraisal/title issues delay closings and the compensation is based on monthly fundings. It’s a tiered systems so it’s frustrating when your files are pushed back to the next month sometimes causing you to miss a higher pay tier - operations and underwriting teams sometimes mess up loans in processing. Leads are overall excellent but the new “warm transfer” system is quite frustrating and makes the leads harder to convert. Luckily most leads are not provided this way and are simply transferred over

title: Great company
pros: Flexible work hours; great management
cons: With this company I experienced no cons.

title: Loans
pros: Work from home was good
cons: There is No job security

title: You can do better
pros: Free lunch and breakfast when working in office
cons: Low pay, no remote work

title: Investor Services
pros: Hybrid schedule 3 days office 2 days home
cons: Overall Micro Managing team culture

title: Great Career Opportunity
pros: Focused on Customer Service Diversity and Inclusion Driving Efficiencies and Quality in Work
cons: Fast paced Working from Home is career limiting option

pros: Company culture and communication is pretty good
cons: Pay is really really bad. Always 30% - 40% under market rate

title: Compensation
pros: The Culture of diversity and inclusion
cons: Unfortunately the entire sales department was laid off due to interest rate hikes nationwide

title: Good
pros: PennyMac offered Good pay, easy to make money quickly
cons: They weren’t very understanding with time off requests

title: Great Company. Great Culture
pros: Great Experience and Opportunity for learning and growth
cons: High Turnover due to Market

title: Stay away!
pros: Save the stress and pressure. Go elsewhere
cons: Just go elsewhere to work

title: Exciting Environment
pros: Plenty of exposure to multiple languages and architectures
cons: Some internal teams are not as proffesional as you would expect

title: good pricing
pros: systems and pricing were good
cons: rude management and toxic environment

title: Good review
pros: Catered lunch was nice during Covid
cons: No business, they let the entire department go.

title: Glad I switched careers
pros: Penny Mac is an amazing company to work for. I have been working for over a year now and enjoy it very much. They always put their employees first. Within days of the pandemic outbreak, they had almost 100% of the company working from home. In addition to keeping our jobs through the crisis, they sent us care packages letting us know they appreciate us. Nothing like opening a package with 4 pints of ice cream in the middle of summer. I can't thank them enough for that. In addition they have this amazing app called vitality that allows you to work towards health goals. When you reach certain metrics, your health insurance is reduced. I love this app and wish I had known about it in my previous career. The managers are great and there is room for advancement which is very nice. I am so thankful to be working here.
cons: There really are no cons. It is a great place to work with lots of benefits and room for advancement.

title: From LO in port 2 years later SM for NCA in Nashville
pros: I've been in the industry for 10 years this april (2022) working in purchase, builder and now call center refinances. Pnmac is a compliance company that also happens to originate loans. The LO comes first and it funnels down to mgmt. As a Sales manager of a team of 9 LO's I can tell you we take very good care of our staff. Even in the changing market PNMAC is big enough to have great rates to offer and small enough to be mobile and navigate the market. Pay is excellent as are the benefits
cons: It may shock some folks out there but you actually have to work for your income here. Don't get me wrong everyone employed here makes a great wage but the ones that make the big dollars all have the same thing in common; They work harder and smarter than those that don't

title: Not a loan processing position - beware
pros: Some people that work here are nice. That’s it.
cons: Management is terrible and out of touch. Pay is below average. No opportunities to move up. No raises. Loan Processors are more like glorified customers service, nothing like other mortgage companies that have files assigned to you. In this place they assign you files but expect you to also get involved in other files that you have nothing to do with. There are so many people involved in the file yet the surveys they send only reflect on you (bonus is affected by bad surveys) . So if you did a great job, if someone answered my call and did a bad job my survey is affected. I have never been so confused as to what managements intentions are with this ridiculous process that they can fix by just letting us work like normal loan processors. I have done loan processing before and PennyMac has another idea of what it is. Most of out customers are upset because they are confused on who to speak to. If PennyMacs focus was on customer service, well they failed miserably. If you are looking for a loan processing job, save yourself the grief and dissatisfaction you will feel once you realize its just a customer service job.

title: They Over-Hire and Then They Fire
pros: They're really into "office culture" which is a cubicle farm that sometimes does things nobody wants, like ice cream socials. I guess if you're into doing non-work related things at work or other Mandated Fun Activities, you may enjoy it here when they force us back to office.
cons: Where to start? They over-hire and then they mass fire. They just laid off hundred of employees after over-hiring AGAIN. They have done this twice in the last year alone. If you were smart enough to look them up before accepting the job and are reading this review, just know that they will drop you the very second business slows down. In the meeting they just held announcing the mass layoffs, they reassured us that those remaining would not be laid off and they may actually be looking to hire in third quarter (three months from right now). Just goes to show you how they "value" employees. They also will not give you a raise. You know who got a raise this year? The CEO. He already made 12 million a year, and the rest of us are making 18/hour, but I'm sure he needs that money more.

title: Layoffs every quarter
pros: Cafeteria in building serves really good chilaquiles.
cons: Management will call you on an approved day off and interrogate why you are not working. This call will ALWAYS be from the one person that handles the schedule and approved you PTO.

title: Customer Service
pros: Standard paid position for department per job market standards. Willingness to improve internal workflows and protocols. Room to improve upon Corp standards.
cons: Direct incidents of violations of the internal employee handbook Corp Anti-harassment policy and procedure. Violations of federal law. Incidents of verbal abuse and harassment btw internal employees during training.

title: Decent
pros: Hybrid work environment, some supportive team members.
cons: Learn on your own, minimal growth, weird culture

title: Bottom of the barrell
pros: Due to the lack of resources and structure, it allows you to gain experience in other areas to help grow your career.
cons: Poor management, no structure, poor compensation, over-worked, upper management has no respect towards their employees (some get yelled at by VIP's), unreasonable/unrealistic expectations, lots of run around excuses when it comes to salary increases or promotions (they try to prolong it and keep it from happening as much as possible), has a terrible approach to improving technology, and poor IT service. Technical issues never get better, they are repetitive with no improvement from the start of the company. Lots of downtime due to technical issues. Increased responsibilities with no increase in compensation. New hires with less experience and less responsibilities are making much more than people who've been with the company for years with more experience and responsibilities. In some cases, manager's are making less than their employees. There is so much politics involved in this place, the same people involved in Countrywide's fraud work at the company. The company requires some dept. to work from Monday - Sunday. Absolutely to work/life balance. This company brings the worse out of people and is not worth the stress. This company is about quantity over quality in all aspects.

title: Great Company. Great People. Great Loan Officer Sales Manager.
pros: Adam Adoree = Great Sales Manager. The Moorpark Loan Officer Manager, is fantastic and supportive of his loan officers, especially during LO's early training days. Really nice man who knows how to motivate LO's. Great long term, monthly training. Friendly co-worker Loan Officers who help each other inside the office. Good Team of Loan Officers. Best Sales Manager I ever had. Honestly. He will recognize this review, since I was the oldest LO he ever hired in 2019. He truly was a unique manager with incredible motivation skills. I miss him already. If my wife's family health issues hadn't taken me away so quickly, I would have worked for him...for many years. Loan Officers, please apply with confidence. Good Company. Great Sales Manager.
cons: All phone calls recorded and reviewed for mistakes constantly. Not always fair review. Difficult to remain on daily monitored schedule. Upper management always commenting on daily production without real understanding on the lower levels of Loan Officer struggles.

title: Toxic, Nepotism, Horrible
pros: On-site cafeteria and gym. There are some cool people working here,but your common hate for your management isn't a healthy environment enough to stay.
cons: Nepotism runs rampant. Managers in the tax department sleep around with each other and hire and promote their friends from past employers. Everyone higher up is related to someone either by blood or marriage. The Nepotism is horrendous and the vibe is very high school clique. "Yes" people get promoted yet complain about their management. Management makes up their own way of how things should be processed without consulting the actual employees doing the work. The company is a joke and human resources does nothing to investigate the horrible management even when entire departments quit. Toxic environment and raises are not given unless you are promoted and are friends with management. Managers also let the friends they hired take 2 hour lunches and give them minimal work.

title: Underwriting Manager
pros: Culture, values, diversity, and inclusion.
cons: Micro Managed by Senior Leadership

title: Account Executive
pros: Plenty of leads coming from a growing portfolio. It's easier to get refi apps when you already service the mortgage. Hourly base (approx. 30K/yr) + per loan bonus. Some flexibility for job start/end times. Multi-state footprint.
cons: Processing is lacking, many aspects had to be handled by sales or it wouldn't get done. Slow turn times. Files closing is 60-90 days. Standard pricing not competitive. Special incentive pricing closer to where rest of the market is. Sales managers are do little to provide support when needed most. PennyMac doesn't operate as a sales-based organization, but rather focuses on processors and pays them very well. Loan Officer comp plan is constantly changing and they most incentive adjusters are negative. Your bonus is always at risk and subject to multiple hits with all the metrics sales must adhere to. Ditch the scripts and adopt a call check list.

title: Overworked and overtired
pros: It took a few minutes to think of some pros.... and I still haven't really come up with anything. I think the only thing I can really say is that the goal to try to deliver a great consumer experience is admirable. That was what I bought into - a company with a mission to truly help homebuyers. I've been there and the process can be overwhelming, so the mission became really important to me.
cons: There's constant change in management and direction. So that mission that you signed on for? Sometimes you're able to work toward it and sometimes it doesn't really matter. At the end of the day, it's about the company being profitable - just like most companies out there. You are literally treated like a child and god forbid if you are paid salary - that means you just have open availability to work whenever they want you to work. You can't do that? Be prepared to hear about it. The expectation is when they call, you run. Life/work balance? What's that? Are you a hard worker? That's great. But don't expect a raise or promotion anytime soon - that takes a few years. Personally, the compensation and benefits you are given do not match your responsibilities and what is expected of you.

title: Culture of Incompetence
pros: Company facilities always located close to freeway exits.
cons: Ineptitude and incompetence at all levels is treated as an open secret and widely tolerated with seldom, if any, consequences for shoddy output. Far too much time is wasted looking for and correcting the errors of lower level employees upon which critical work is based. Management is wildly unimpressive, lacking strong leadership abilities and the basic capability to command a staff effectively to accomplish goals and tasks in a timely manner with positive results. Company has a seat-of-the-pants, Wild West style. “Let’s throw this at the wall and see if it sticks” is not an efficient corporate governance strategy. Pay is mediocre, at best. Career advancement appears based on lunchtime and after work socializing prowess rather than hard skills, demonstration of competence and documented accomplishments. Too many potlucks, free cafeteria lunches and useless company-branded trinket giveaways as opposed to meaningful pay increases (for those deserving based on performance) or investment in better health benefits.

title: Dead end job
pros: They make you pay $20 a month to wear jeans to work. I guess the only pro is that they donate that money to a charity.
cons: No career advancement. And when the do offer any type of new position it's always a lateral move. There is no bonus or annual raise payout. Worked with a guy who has been there over 3 years and has never gotten a raise. He's a top performer too. This company is where careers go to die. They will tell you everything you want to hear to get you in, but then you're trapped. I never realized how much I hated this place until I wasn't there anymore. Ran by all the old Countrywide execs. All they care about is how much you can help them line their pockets, all the while pushing you for more and more production. Just a glorified sweatshop. Good riddance!!!!

title: Don’t do it. Seriously
pros: You will learn a lot about the the mortgage industry. Most of the other representatives and some of the managers are really amazing people.
cons: It’s a call center job so you are non stop taking inbound calls from mostly very angry customers. Extremely micromanaged. Your entire day is monitored from the moment you sign in until you sign out, including all your bathroom breaks. If you get stuck on a long call and go late to your breaks or lunch, it counts against your metrics for the month. Everything is recorded and managers will plug into a call from the desk to listen in. As well as the control tower( who monitors how the call queue.) if your calls are longer then 6 minutes it will count against your monthly metrics. New employees get 3 sick days, so use them wisely. You will get written up if you go over them. Vacation time must be accrued before any request can be made. There is always OT offered, which you will have to sign up for because you can’t survive on the extremely low hourly rate they offer. I am not exaggerating any of these things. This job is extremely demoralizing and mentally, spiritually crushing.

title: I love PennyMac
pros: Since coming to PennyMac I have been blown away at the growth and empowerment Ive experienced. Beginning with little experience I was quickly brought up to speed and exposed to many facets of the industry I had never experienced. The fast paced work environment rewards commitment and resolve, and you can quickly grow your career so long as you're willing to do the work and have the conversations. The managers I work with are experienced, knowledgeable, and incredibly hardworking which makes a world of difference in the day to day. Culture as well as Diversity/Inclusion are taken very seriously by the company, whether its gift baskets, holiday gifts, food trucks, ice cream socials, or activities such as trivia, vision boards, and toy drives - there is always something going on at PennyMac. The company has endless roles or departments or channels to work in, so you will always find a fit for you and your talents.
cons: Raises and promotions are done during scheduled times, as well as rules regarding how much percentage of a raise you can receive during a given time period. Its very difficult (not impossible) to get anything "off cycle" or to receive sizable raises.

title: Reliable Gatekeepers
pros: Most of your co-workers are very nice and competent people. There is a lot of camaraderie on your individual team. Remote Position(for now)
cons: There are virtually no suggested raises it is all based on performance and applying for the next position. All of the managers are constantly afraid and overworked which makes for a tense environment. You are just a number to them and a lot of social favoritism is factored into each managerial decision. Your manager is your gatekeeper and they ultimately decide if you move up in the company or not. The change in pace or call structure can become a nuisance.

title: Would try to avoid
pros: Good co workers Decent starting pay Cater food sometimes
cons: Been in the same role for almost 3 years, still not promoted or have an increase in pay when working several Loan programs. When needing to take a half day off for a DR appt management tries to guilt you for not being at work. Cares more about being in office and planning to take WFH equipment away. Didn't tell staff that someone had COVID in office so we can quarantine and stop the spread. Management acts like they can do as they please (IE leaves for minuscule reasons but lord forbid we need to leave for a DR appt that has been told for 3 months). This is not a "job secure" job no matter how much they preach it. Three lay-offs in less than 2 months. OH, and lastly. This job is a call center. If you do not want to work at a call center, don't apply.

title: Great Culture!
pros: Great culture! This is a very different environment then other mortgage companies I have worked for, everyone is very friendly and helpful here! Great on-boarding process and training experience. The company has grown at a steady pace over the past few years and if your looking for job security this is the place to be.
cons: The benefits are not that great as well as don't count on getting a raise and if you do it is never anything substantial. 401k matching is only 4% after a year of service and you only have 2 weeks of vacation for the first 5 years of employment. Negotiate the hack out of your pay in the beginning because no matter how hard your work, your previous back ground, being the perfect employee getting a raise here just doesn't happen on a routine basis, there is not a annual merit increase. Because of the slow and steady growth, which is great sign of longevity, unfortunately there are not a lot of advancement opportunities, basically if someone is not moving up or out neither will you.

title: Horrible Place to Work
pros: Parking lot has fresh pavement
cons: You will be surrounded by miserable people who constantly complain about their low pay

title: All of the politics of a legacy company with none of the large company benefits
pros: • A lot to learn / Interesting work • Potentially competitive Pay • Decent medical benefits • Top-notch cafeteria
cons: #1) Directors create silos around their departments and you spend so much time trying to get people to cooperate/communicate, until you inevitably fail and then you spend more time figuring out how to get done what you need to without support. #2) You get paid what you fight for. Don't expect recognition, appreciation, or compensation. You get rewarded when you demand it and threaten to quite if they don't deliver. Managers will work you into an early grave if you let them. #3) The worst PTO policy and Bonus payment policy. #4) Culture of fear. Managers care more about assigning blame and belittling you than about solutions and improvement. #5) Lying is rewarded. #6) Toxic managers abound. Managers will sabotage your work and career in order to ensure their own longevity. #7) The office providers no personal space or privacy and has too few bathrooms.

title: No Salary Raises! Can't Save More Than 6 Sick Days, Ever
pros: its a nice building. thanks.
cons: Stop sending announcements saying how PennyMac is beating records, etc. If PennyMac is doing so great, start giving raises. How do you expect people to stay working here and tell them you only get a raise if you get promoted! Promotions are rare. Why can't we save more than 6 sick days? After that, you never accumulate any more. You are encouraging people to call in sick. You don't pay us for the sick days if we leave the company, so let us accumulate hours if we are not using them, what's the harm? I watch coworkers call in sick 6 times a year, every year. I never use sick time, yet I only have 6 days on the books after many years of working here.

title: Good Company, Lots of Growth Potential
pros: The culture is relaxed enough to be comfortable, though not necessarily laid back across the board (this typically depends on your department, role and/or manager). Layoffs are non-existent, firings are rare, and most of us trust the direction of the company. And since most people usually get hired as a referral (this isn't the kind of place you simply walk into) there's a unique closeness and sense of camaraderie across the organization, despite the cliques. Work environments are also pleasant, with plenty of perks and resources to help you reach your potential.
cons: There's a ton of variance within the company and its culture across locations. This often makes things more difficult and tedious than they have to be. Expectations are not always clear and management wastes time having meetings about meetings trying to figure out what is (or should be) going on. Favoritism is rampant, but downplayed or completely disregarded. System issues are truly a DAILY headache. (And unlike other PennyMac locations, there's no onsite gym or cafeteria.)

title: PennyMac.... is it worth it?
pros: Love the people I work with. The culture in Los Angeles offices is great, I hear.
cons: *** If you expect a bonus make sure the language is included in your offer letter. DO NOT EXPECT to receive a bonus based upon merit, hard work, & stellar performance review (it won't happen!) *** Benefits are sub-par compared to other real estate finance companies. Medical offered, but VERY expensive if you add spouse and/or children. Vacation: (everyone receives the same, there is NO negotiating) • FVP and below receive 10 vacation days per year, accrued at 3.33 hours • SVP and above receive 15 days per year, accrued at 5 hours Sick Time: (everyone receives the same, there is NO negotiating) 6 days per year, accrued at 2 hours per pay period of service. Recognized Holidays: • New Year’s Day (Jan 1) • Martin Luther King Jr. Day (3rd Monday in January) • Presidents’ Day (3rd Monday in February) • Memorial Day (last Monday in May) • Independence Day (July 4) • Labor Day (1st Monday in September) • Thanksgiving (4th Thursday in November) • Christmas (December 25) • One Alternative Holiday

title: A true work family environment
pros: First of all the pay is amazing. Also, when it comes to your work experience they give you a real chance to learn about the mortgage industry. You actually get at least 5 weeks of training so that when you go out on the floor and you start working you really feel like you know what you're doing. There is also opportunity for overtime all of the time. Which is nice if you are ever in need of extra money and you want to do that math you know what you need to do how many hours into work, in order to get the money that you need. I would say the best part about working here is that you really feel like you are working with friends and family. You get a supervisor who has a team, and you have meetings at least once or twice a month. Outside of that there is the opportunity to get sale bonuses each month, but it is not required in a sense of you have to push sales it is nearly an opportunity while having a conversation with a customer. Oh and not to mention, they have their own cafeteria that you get a free meal tickets for whenever you work 30 minute lunches.
cons: If you are used to having your weekends to yourself, then working at PennyMac may not be a good idea for you. I only say this because every other Saturday we do have to work 4 hours. However these four hours are in the morning and you do get a break. I myself, actually enjoy working every other Saturday because I mean spend every other Saturday you know you are guaranteed overtime so it really depends on how you look at things. The only other con working there is that it is quite far for most people however they are working on expanding so soon there actually be two locations for customer service.

title: Unnecessary headaches for nothing
pros: I was able to apply my programming skills in a very diverse business environment. flexible lunch hours.
cons: Project requirements kept changing and no clear problem statement and as a result must be available to work more than 2 hours on a daily basis, On the top of it, my manager did not take responsibility of poor data gathering and blamed me on not meeting deadlines. When I got headaches,I tried to sneak out after finishing 8 hours. After few occurrences of leaving early, I had a very unstructured meeting of my career with management. I wanted to quit in the meeting but I am not rich yet so I stayed until I found a better job.

title: HORRIBLE
pros: Ot and used to get food.
cons: My my my. Let me start with the interview were they lie and say you'll get some call here and there. Complete lie. The inbound calls are horrendous. No company should be selfish to have a system set up like this craziness but then again they care about money. By any means possible to get it. Management are questionable. Training... what training?? 🤨 They make sure you are at that seat taking the back to back calls. Ohhh don't have an escalate call, some managers dodge the messages 🙄 so that they don't have to deal and help with the issue. But in EVERY MEETING you are scolded as a child what other debts should be doing it All falls on you at the end. Management are quick to cover the other debts lack of work duty, which is shameful in all their parts Front liners are UNDERPAID for the craziness faced on the daily basis Don't get me started on the bonus, lmaoooo the plan they have in place.

title: Beware!
pros: I have nothing that I could put in here with the exception of the office gym and almost being able to pay the bills.
cons: I have never worked at a place where there are no chance of raises. Step increase over a year! Who are they kidding? People are getting promoted for 2-3% and oh they promise bonuses... But for stock that matures in several years. This is the cheapest company that I have every worked for and would not work here unless you are desperate! They have the mind set that if you are desperate for a job you will deal with the 2 week vacation (you have to accrue) 5 day sick, low pay and outrageous medical costs. There is also no concept of accountability for management. They try their hardest to sweep things under the carpet and hide from regulators. Some really shady things go on! CFPB or OCC would have a field day if they spoke to the right people.

pros: Nothing besides working and being employed
cons: Everything was bad not a good company

title: A Great Place to Work
pros: PennyMac has been the best company to work for. Management is very approachable, most are former loan officers that understand the difficulties of the job. - Warm inbound leads mostly from our large portfolio. Customers know who we are and receive direct marketing to call us directly instead of a third party mortgage website. We have dispatch teams that work hard to keep are phones ringing. -Very competitive pay compared to most mortgage lenders. Not many restrictions on OT, so you can always put in more hours to boost your pay. -Good work life balance. You don't have to take work home and won't be contacted on your cell or personal email. -This is a growing company that seems to always be hiring, advancements are merit based. -A lot of free lunches have been provided lately
cons: -Medical benefits are expensive -There has been an increasing amount of operational work for loan officers which cuts into the amount of time we can spend getting more loans

title: Overworked
pros: Team manager and co-workers are great.
cons: Benefits are not great. They make a big deal about insurance rates not increasing, but the annual deductible went up. Bereavement leave is in adequate. You get 3 days for a relative in state. 5 Days if they are out of state. Two weeks of pto for the first 5 years and after year five you get three weeks. This is inadequate as well. There are no annual raises. They expect a minimum of 50 hours a week. They are not flexible regarding working from home. They expect everyone to return to the office after Covid, even though many employees have spoken out about wanting to continue to work from home because of the many benefits it provides. Work itself is very chaotic and unorganized. It's often difficult to get assistance and they provide very little training. Upper management gives canned responses for legitimate questions. They don't care what the employees want.

title: Awful Tech Culture
pros: No pros to mention about now.
cons: Company has no idea what business analysts and project managers are supposed to do when it comes to IT. They trust their project managers too much and are obsessed with ticket pointing but the project managers don't even understand code so how would they evaluate whether a developer is pointing correctly? The most unproductive devs would give themselves lots of points while the most productive devs would be honest but look "bad" to the eyes of the project managers. But the project managers and business analysts were completely clueless.

title: Can you say B of A 2.0?
pros: Stable . M-F ok benefits
cons: Since most of upper management came from B of A which does a horrible job as a mortgage company it is run the exact same way . All loan activities are tasked to about 12 different people who most know nothing about the business . Your day is spent checking what every person who touches the file does . 80% of the time it wasn’t either completed or it was done incorrectly . Lots of conference calls that are more about making people feel included rather than improvements in the company. But hey they send you gifts occasionally and woke millennials live that stuff . If you want a mindless , repetitive job to collect your pay then this is the place for you . If you actually have a brain and want to use it .. go work elsewhere. Typical large corporation.

title: In what world does an employer not give raises...at all!
pros: - Fun co-workers - Not very stressful of a position - Supervisors are nice and have your best interest in mind but their hands are tied when it comes to making decisions on raises/comp etc.
